segment.source: Learn to develop accessible Windows 10 UWP apps that include keyboard navigation, color and contrast settings, and support for assistive technologies.
segment.target: Learn to develop accessible Windows 10 UWP apps that include keyboard navigation, color and contrast settings, and support for assistive technologies.

segment.source: This article discusses how to develop accessible Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article discusses how to develop accessible Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: Specifically, it assumes that you understand how to design the logical hierarchy for your app.
segment.target: Specifically, it assumes that you understand how to design the logical hierarchy for your app.

segment.source: If you have not yet done so, please start by reading Designing inclusive Software.
segment.target: If you have not yet done so, please start by reading Designing inclusive Software.

segment.source: There are three things you should do to make sure that your app is accessible:
segment.target: There are three things you should do to make sure that your app is accessible:

segment.source: Expose your UI elements to programmatic access.
segment.target: Expose your UI elements to programmatic access.

segment.source: Ensure that your app supports keyboard navigation for people who are unable to use a mouse or touchscreen.
segment.target: Ensure that your app supports keyboard navigation for people who are unable to use a mouse or touchscreen.

segment.source: Make sure that your app supports accessible color and contrast settings.
segment.target: Make sure that your app supports accessible color and contrast settings.

segment.source: Programmatic access
segment.target: Programmatic access

segment.source: Programmatic access is critical for creating accessibility in apps.
segment.target: Programmatic access is critical for creating accessibility in apps.

segment.source: This is achieved by setting the accessible name (required) and description (optional) for content and interactive UI elements in your app.
segment.target: This is achieved by setting the accessible name (required) and description (optional) for content and interactive UI elements in your app.

segment.source: This ensures that UI controls are exposed to assistive technology (AT) such as screen readers (for example, Narrator) or alternative output devices (such as Braille displays).
segment.target: This ensures that UI controls are exposed to assistive technology (AT) such as screen readers (for example, Narrator) or alternative output devices (such as Braille displays).

segment.source: Without programmatic access, the APIs for assistive technology cannot interpret information correctly, leaving the user unable to use the products sufficiently, or forcing the AT to use undocumented programming interfaces or techniques never intended to be used as an accessibility interface.
segment.target: Without programmatic access, the APIs for assistive technology cannot interpret information correctly, leaving the user unable to use the products sufficiently, or forcing the AT to use undocumented programming interfaces or techniques never intended to be used as an accessibility interface.

segment.source: When UI controls are exposed to assistive technology, the AT is able to determine what actions and options are available to the user.
segment.target: When UI controls are exposed to assistive technology, the AT is able to determine what actions and options are available to the user.

segment.source: For more information about making your app UI elements available to assistive technologies (AT), see Expose basic accessibility information.
segment.target: For more information about making your app UI elements available to assistive technologies (AT), see Expose basic accessibility information.

segment.source: Keyboard navigation
segment.target: Keyboard navigation

segment.source: For users who are blind or have mobility issues, being able to navigate the UI with a keyboard is extremely important.
segment.target: For users who are blind or have mobility issues, being able to navigate the UI with a keyboard is extremely important.

segment.source: However, only those UI controls that require user interaction to function should be given keyboard focus.
segment.target: However, only those UI controls that require user interaction to function should be given keyboard focus.

segment.source: Components that don’t require an action, such as static images, do not need keyboard focus.
segment.target: Components that don’t require an action, such as static images, do not need keyboard focus.

segment.source: It is important to remember that unlike navigating with a mouse or touch, keyboard navigation is linear.
segment.target: It is important to remember that unlike navigating with a mouse or touch, keyboard navigation is linear.

segment.source: When considering keyboard navigation, think about how your user will interact with your product and what the logical navigation will be.
segment.target: When considering keyboard navigation, think about how your user will interact with your product and what the logical navigation will be.

segment.source: In Western cultures, people read from left to right, top to bottom.
segment.target: In Western cultures, people read from left to right, top to bottom.

segment.source: It is, therefore, common practice to follow this pattern for keyboard navigation.
segment.target: It is, therefore, common practice to follow this pattern for keyboard navigation.

segment.source: When designing keyboard navigation, examine your UI, and think about these questions:
segment.target: When designing keyboard navigation, examine your UI, and think about these questions:

segment.source: How are the controls laid out or grouped in the UI?
segment.target: How are the controls laid out or grouped in the UI?

segment.source: Are there a few significant groups of controls?
segment.target: Are there a few significant groups of controls?

segment.source: If yes, do those groups contain another level of groups?
segment.target: If yes, do those groups contain another level of groups?

segment.source: Among peer controls, should navigation be done by tabbing around, or via special navigation (such as arrow keys), or both?
segment.target: Among peer controls, should navigation be done by tabbing around, or via special navigation (such as arrow keys), or both?

segment.source: The goal is to help the user understand how the UI is laid out and identify the controls that are actionable.
segment.target: The goal is to help the user understand how the UI is laid out and identify the controls that are actionable.

segment.source: If you are finding that there are too many tab stops before the user completes the navigation loop, consider grouping related controls together.
segment.target: If you are finding that there are too many tab stops before the user completes the navigation loop, consider grouping related controls together.

segment.source: Some controls that are related, such as a hybrid control, may need to be addressed at this early exploration stage.
segment.target: Some controls that are related, such as a hybrid control, may need to be addressed at this early exploration stage.

segment.source: After you begin to develop your product, it is difficult to rework the keyboard navigation, so plan carefully and plan early!
segment.target: After you begin to develop your product, it is difficult to rework the keyboard navigation, so plan carefully and plan early!

segment.source: To learn more about keyboard navigation among UI elements, see Keyboard accessibility.
segment.target: To learn more about keyboard navigation among UI elements, see Keyboard accessibility.

segment.source: Also, the Engineering Software for Accessibility eBook has an excellent chapter on this subject titled Designing the Logical Hierarchy.
segment.target: Also, the Engineering Software for Accessibility eBook has an excellent chapter on this subject titled Designing the Logical Hierarchy.

segment.source: Color and contrast
segment.target: Color and contrast

segment.source: One of the built-in accessibility features in Windows is the High Contrast mode, which heightens the color contrast of text and images on the computer screen.
segment.target: One of the built-in accessibility features in Windows is the High Contrast mode, which heightens the color contrast of text and images on the computer screen.

segment.source: For some people, increasing the contrast in colors reduces eyestrain and makes it easier to read.
segment.target: For some people, increasing the contrast in colors reduces eyestrain and makes it easier to read.

segment.source: When you verify your UI in high contrast, you want to check that controls have been coded consistently and with system colors (not with hard-coded colors) to ensure that they will be able to see all the controls on the screen that a user not using high contrast would see.
segment.target: When you verify your UI in high contrast, you want to check that controls have been coded consistently and with system colors (not with hard-coded colors) to ensure that they will be able to see all the controls on the screen that a user not using high contrast would see.

segment.source: XAML
segment.target: XAML

segment.source: For more information about using system colors and resources, see XAML theme resources.
segment.target: For more information about using system colors and resources, see XAML theme resources.

segment.source: As long as you haven’t overridden system colors, a UWP app supports high-contrast themes by default.
segment.target: As long as you haven’t overridden system colors, a UWP app supports high-contrast themes by default.

segment.source: If a user has chosen that they want the system to use a high-contrast theme from system settings or accessibility tools, the framework automatically uses colors and style settings that produce a high-contrast layout and rendering for controls and components in the UI.
segment.target: If a user has chosen that they want the system to use a high-contrast theme from system settings or accessibility tools, the framework automatically uses colors and style settings that produce a high-contrast layout and rendering for controls and components in the UI.

segment.source: For more information, see High-contrast themes.
segment.target: For more information, see High-contrast themes.

segment.source: If you have decided to use you own color theme instead of system colors, consider these guidelines:
segment.target: If you have decided to use you own color theme instead of system colors, consider these guidelines:

segment.source: Color contrast ratio – The updated Section 508 of the Americans with Disability Act, as well as other legislation, requires that the default color contrasts between text and its background must be 5:1.
segment.target: Color contrast ratio – The updated Section 508 of the Americans with Disability Act, as well as other legislation, requires that the default color contrasts between text and its background must be 5:1.

segment.source: For large text (18-point font sizes, or 14 points and bolded), the required default contrast is 3:1.
segment.target: For large text (18-point font sizes, or 14 points and bolded), the required default contrast is 3:1.

segment.source: Color combinations – About 7 percent of males (and less than 1 percent of females) have some form of color deficiency.
segment.target: Color combinations – About 7 percent of males (and less than 1 percent of females) have some form of color deficiency.

segment.source: Users with colorblindness have problems distinguishing between certain colors, so it is important that color alone is never used to convey status or meaning in an application.
segment.target: Users with colorblindness have problems distinguishing between certain colors, so it is important that color alone is never used to convey status or meaning in an application.

segment.source: As for decorative images (such as icons or backgrounds), color combinations should be chosen in a manner that maximizes the perception of the image by colorblind users.
segment.target: As for decorative images (such as icons or backgrounds), color combinations should be chosen in a manner that maximizes the perception of the image by colorblind users.

segment.source: Accessibility checklist
segment.target: Accessibility checklist

segment.source: Following is an abbreviated version of the accessibility checklist:
segment.target: Following is an abbreviated version of the accessibility checklist:

segment.source: Set the accessible name (required) and description (optional) for content and interactive UI elements in your app.
segment.target: Set the accessible name (required) and description (optional) for content and interactive UI elements in your app.

segment.source: Implement keyboard accessibility.
segment.target: Implement keyboard accessibility.

segment.source: Visually verify your UI to ensure that the text contrast is adequate, elements render correctly in the high-contrast themes, and colors are used correctly.
segment.target: Visually verify your UI to ensure that the text contrast is adequate, elements render correctly in the high-contrast themes, and colors are used correctly.

segment.source: Run accessibility tools, address reported issues, and verify the screen reading experience.
segment.target: Run accessibility tools, address reported issues, and verify the screen reading experience.

segment.source: (See Accessibility testing topic.)
segment.target: (See Accessibility testing topic.)

segment.source: Make sure your app manifest settings follow accessibility guidelines.
segment.target: Make sure your app manifest settings follow accessibility guidelines.

segment.source: Declare your app as accessible in the Windows Store.
segment.target: Declare your app as accessible in the Windows Store.

segment.source: (See the Accessibility in the store topic.)
segment.target: (See the Accessibility in the store topic.)
